When it comes to blazing firepower, I would put my master archmage or archer 
up against any multi-member team. The archer is a good example of 
balance--level 36, but armoured to the point where his own exploding bolts 
do very little damage to himself (well over 300). A cleric is a sitting duck 
for a guy like this, as long as the controller keeps him out of magic mace 
range. Mages and archmages can be taken out by a character half their level 
if they let him get into close combat. Teleporting isn't very effective, as 
you can't target a location (unless you put a marker in a safe zone, behind 
a door or wall). Still, an archer can easily slay someone through a wall or 
two, and an archmage's chain lightning is a scary prospect in cramped 
quarters. I haven't yet perfected the use of barbarians, but they have some 
definite possibilities, as do soldiers. They're just a bit slow for me.

On the topic of how hard is hard--I've been able to beat every level of Tryx 
and DPH's released levels on slaughter with an archmage. They're both 
overpacked, so chain lightning is your best bet. TevFifty is mostly a 
cakewalk, as long as you finished the original 46, with the exceptions of 
The Ocean, The Pyramid, Castle of 2.5 Peaks, and the final scenario. The 
others are doable at Slaughter with a single good character. DPH, let's see 
if your archmage can beat The Ocean... in a normal level you would just blow 
everything up, summon an image of a cleric, have him raise ghosts, and use 
them to search for the hidden areas.... but you can't summon an image over 
water. Perhaps your chain lightning has enough range to hit the hidden 
stuff, perhaps not.

The Ten Inept Mages was an idea my friend Jonas passed over to me... he's 
quite a card, and a creative genius in his own right. All I did was stack a 
few potions in ten location and plunk some level 1 mages and archmages right 
over them. Sometimes the morons teleport just as the level starts, leaving 
behind their stash... making them sitting ducks. I used the same trick in 
the Slime Corrals, so if you cheat and attack the Pet too soon, you'll just 
be zapping an invulnerable blob for five minutes.

Xena fans out there--I was bored, and fooling around with Editor.exe, and 
ended up making the elves throw Chakrams instead of rocks. It's really funny 
to watch them go bouncing off of walls and stuff, or if you give them 
soldiers and make them return like frisbees... I'll put the file (rocks.pix) 
in our Egroups shared files, unzipped so you can see there's no virus, and 
if you want to use it just stick it in your Gladiator folder. To bring back 
the default rocks, just delete the file.

That's all for today, folks... I'll be presenting Tom with a revised version 
of TevFifty pretty soon, to post on the Forgotten Sages site, but don't hold 
your breath... I must have been drunk on life (or something) when I 
playtested it. The teleporters AREN'T foolproof, like I said they were; 
d'oh! Of course, you can still get the original release at 
http://hotyellow98.com/tevildo/glad.html. Later.

     -Tevildo, Prince of Cats.
